item.title: The importance of increasing primary vaccinations against COVID-19 in Europe
Come work with us: open postdoc position @ EV / The modelers
item.description:
Come work with EV / The modelers. We are opening a postdoc position at the lab funded by the European project SIESTA.

We are looking for a motivated researcher wishing to work on data-driven modeling of epidemic spread. We seek expertise either in physics of complex systems / complex networks or in statistical inference, expecially with deep-learning.

You will work on developing new-generation mathematical models of epidemic spread coupling them to large-scale datasets at high spatial and temporal resolution, including human behavior.

Use THIS FORM to apply.

Details:

  • application period: flexible, the position will be filled as soon as we find a suitable candidate;
  • start of the contract: flexible, to be discussed with the candidate. Allow at least two months for the administrative process;
  • duration of the contract: 1.5 years, extendable;
  • employer: Inserm;
  • gross monthly salary: ~3,000 euros for a recent PhD graduate, subject to changes to Inserm salary grids.

item.title: Kickoff meeting of the European project SIESTA
item.description: We will be attending the kick-off meeting of the newly started European project SIESTA.

item.title: Lightning talk at NetSciX
EV / The Modelers now on the Italian ILI Forecast platform Influcast
item.description:
Influcast is platform to forecast the evolution of the incidence of influenza-like-illness in Italy by integrating prediction from multiple teams and models. It is coordinated by the ISI Foundation. EV / The Modelers now provides weekly estimates to Influcast.

Through our collaboration with Influcast, our goal is to push the methodological boundaries of mathematical models. Partnering up with our colleagues at the computer science dept. of the University of Bologna, Italy, we are developing a model that combines mechanistic mathematical modeling of epidemic dynamics with deep-learning based inference from data, using physics-informed neural networks.

The interaction with Influcast allows us to assess and improve the performance of our models in a nowcasting scenario and to benchmark them against existing forecasting frameworks.

item.title: The 5th edition of Complexity72H
item.description:
Apply to the 2024 edition of Complexity72H!

It will take place at the Carlos III University in Madrid, Spain, from June 24 to June 28 2024.

Complexity72h is an interdisciplinary workshop for young researchers in complex systems. Participants form teams and carry out projects in a three days’ time, i.e. 72 hours. The goal of each team is to complete and upload a report of their work by the end of the event.

Thanks to the support of our partners we are keeping very low participation fees so that everyone can apply! Also, we will grant partial and full fee waivers to a selected number of applicants.

Visit our website for all the info! You will find

  • our lecturers
  • our tutors and the projects they are proposing
  • the instructions on how to apply

item.title: Epidemic graph diagrams as analytics for epidemic control in the data-rich era

item.title: IPLESP retreat
item.description: We will be at a 2-day retreat of our institute: the Pierre Louis Institute of Epidemiology and Public Health.

item.title: Annual meeting of the French Consortium 'Infectious Disease Modeling'
item.description:
We will be attending the annual meeting of the Consortium Infectious Disease Modeling - French: Action Coordonnée Modélisation des maladies infectieuses (AC Modélisation) -, of which Eugenio is a member of the Scientific Committee. The AC Modélisation is the network of French epidemic modelers under the umbrella of ANRS-MIE (INSERM agency for the research on HIV, TB, STI, viral hepatitis and emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases).

Claudio will also be presenting a poster.

item.title: The scales of epidemic modeling
item.description:
We are organizing this workshop which is a joint effort of the working groups Mesoscopic Scales of Epidemic Dynamics (coordinated by Eugenio) and Modeling of Within-Host Dynamics of the Action Coordonnée Modélisation des maladies infectieuses of the ANRS-MIE (INSERM agency for the research on HIV, TB, STI, viral hepatitis and emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases).

Our speakers will be Laura Alessandretti, Federico Baldo, Luca Dall’Asta, Raluca Eftimie, Raphaël Forien, Simon Gubbins, Jérémie Guedj, Jose Ramasco.

Check out the full program program and register for free on the website of the event.

This workshop is funded by the AC Modélisation des maladies infectieuses of the ANRS-MIE.

item.title: The role of migration networks in the development of Botswana's generalized HIV epidemic
Estimates of the reproduction ratio from epidemic surveillance may be biased in spatially structured populations
Lightning talk at NetSci
Disruption of outdoor activities caused by wildfire smoke shapes circulation of respiratory pathogens
EpiMob2023 satellite at NetSci 2023
item.description:
We are organizing the second edition of this satellite meeting together with Mattia Mazzoli and Giulia Pullano and Chiara Sabbatini. Our keynote speakers will be

  • Prof. Alex Arenas
  • Prof. Rowland Kao
  • Dr. Amanda Perofsky

We will also have five contributed talks. We’re bound for a great half day! Check out the event website.

Human mobility is a driver of epidemics. Long-range movements drive patterns of pathogen importation and exportation. Short-range mobility fuels local epidemics, by tuning population mixing and transmission rates. This is why the study of patterns of human mobility can tell us why and how epidemics break out and circulate, and inform us on effective prevention and control policies. The current COVID-19 pandemic is proof of this potential.

In the last decades, mobility data coming mostly from mobile devices (phones, smartphones) have informed epidemiological studies: e.g., malaria, cholera, Ebola. But, during this pandemic, we witnessed a data-sharing revolution in which network operators such as Orange, Vodafone, Telefonica, and companies like Google, Apple, Facebook, Cuebiq, SafeGraph, Unacast, started providing their aggregated mobility data extracted from mobile phone traces in real-time. This new resource is, however, also a challenge. Epidemiological research is in the process of developing new tools, and models, to integrate these data and use them both for retrospective analysis of epidemic dynamics, and for active surveillance and epidemic monitoring, at higher spatial resolution than ever before.

​The satellite aims at gathering researchers working on the use of mobility data for the study of, and response to, infectious disease epidemics. We welcome both methodological studies, aiming at integrating data and epidemic models, and applied projects, showing the potential of mobility data for public health action and epidemic response.

item.title: Complexity72H
item.description:
Complexity72H is back after COVID.

Complexity72h is an interdisciplinary workshop for young researchers in complex systems. Participants form teams and carry out projects in a three days’ time, i.e. 72 hours. The goal of each team is to upload on the arXiv (or similar repositories) a report of their work by the end of the event. The editions of 2018 and 2019 were a success: 11 out of 11 projects have become arXiv preprints and new collaborations have been born. The 2020 edition was canceled due to the pandemic. But we are now back for a 2023 edition in Palma (Mallorca, Spain) on June 26-30.

APPLY HERE until Jan 31, 2023.

item.title: Complexity72H is back!
item.description:
Complexity72H is back after COVID.

Complexity72h is an interdisciplinary workshop for young researchers in complex systems. Participants form teams and carry out projects in a three days’ time, i.e. 72 hours. The goal of each team is to upload on the arXiv (or similar repositories) a report of their work by the end of the event. The editions of 2018 and 2019 were a success: 11 out of 11 projects have become arXiv preprints and new collaborations have been born. The 2020 edition was canceled due to the pandemic. But we are now back for a 2023 edition, which will take place in Palma (Mallorca, Spain) on June 26-30.

Check our the call for tutors and the call for applications on our website!

Keynote talk at Complex Systems for the Most Vulnerable
item.description: I will be a keynote speaker at this satellite. I will address how data-rich mathematical modeling may help to unveil inequalities, and improve the welfare of those who are most vulnerable to, and burdened by, infectious disease epidemics.

item.title: Talk at Pasteur Institute
Lecture at IFISC Summer School
EpiMob Satellite @ NetSci2022
item.description:
I am organizing this satellite meeting together with Mattia Mazzoli and Giulia Pullano. Our keynote speakers will be

  • Prof. Shweta Bansal
  • Prof. Dirk Brockmann
  • Prof. Andrew J Tatem

Human mobility is a driver of epidemics. Long-range movements drive patterns of pathogen importation and exportation. Short-range mobility fuels local epidemics, by tuning population mixing and transmission rates. This is why the study of patterns of human mobility can tell us why and how epidemics break out and circulate, and inform us on effective prevention and control policies. The current COVID-19 pandemic is proof of this potential.

In the last decades, mobility data coming mostly from mobile devices (phones, smartphones) have informed epidemiological studies: e.g., malaria, cholera, Ebola. But, during this pandemic, we witnessed a data-sharing revolution in which network operators such as Orange, Vodafone, Telefonica, and companies like Google, Apple, Facebook, Cuebiq, SafeGraph, Unacast, started providing their aggregated mobility data extracted from mobile phone traces in real-time. This new resource is, however, also a challenge. Epidemiological research is in the process of developing new tools, and models, to integrate these data and use them both for retrospective analysis of epidemic dynamics, and for active surveillance and epidemic monitoring, at higher spatial resolution than ever before.

​The satellite aims at gathering researchers working on the use of mobility data for the study of, and response to, infectious disease epidemics. We welcome both methodological studies, aiming at integrating data and epidemic models, and applied projects, showing the potential of mobility data for public health action and epidemic response.

To know more, and to sumbit your abstract, visit our event website - the deadline to sumbit is June 8, 2022!

item.title: Contributed talk at BIFI International Conference
Non-selective distribution of infectious disease prevention may outperform risk-based targeting
EpiMob2022 satellite at NetSci on Jul 11, 2022
item.description:
I am organizing this satellite meeting together with Mattia Mazzoli and Giulia Pullano. Our keynote speakers will be

  • Prof. Shweta Bansal
  • Prof. Dirk Brockmann
  • Prof. Andrew J Tatem

We will also have six contributed talks. We’re bound for a great half day! The program will be soon available on the event website.

Human mobility is a driver of epidemics. Long-range movements drive patterns of pathogen importation and exportation. Short-range mobility fuels local epidemics, by tuning population mixing and transmission rates. This is why the study of patterns of human mobility can tell us why and how epidemics break out and circulate, and inform us on effective prevention and control policies. The current COVID-19 pandemic is proof of this potential.

In the last decades, mobility data coming mostly from mobile devices (phones, smartphones) have informed epidemiological studies: e.g., malaria, cholera, Ebola. But, during this pandemic, we witnessed a data-sharing revolution in which network operators such as Orange, Vodafone, Telefonica, and companies like Google, Apple, Facebook, Cuebiq, SafeGraph, Unacast, started providing their aggregated mobility data extracted from mobile phone traces in real-time. ​The satellite aims at gathering researchers working on the use of mobility data for the study of, and response to, infectious disease epidemics. We welcome both methodological studies, aiming at integrating data and epidemic models, and applied projects, showing the potential of mobility data for public health action and epidemic response.
